archdesc.bioghist: Rev. James Billings was a Universalist minister, editor, publisher, and missionary. In 1843 he edited, with others, the Ann Arbor, Mich. religious publication "The Primitive Expounder." In 1844 he was one of the founders of the Alphadelphia Association, a commune near Galesburg, Mich. (disbanded in 1848). Between 1844 and 1846 Billings published "Alphadelphia Tocsin," commune's newsletter. Approximately in 1845 Billings moved to Jackson, Mich. Nathaniel Stacy (1778-1868) was a Universalist clergyman and evangelist active in New York, Western Pennsylvania, and Michigan Territory, where he helped organize Michigan's first Universalist association and headed the church in Ann Arbor, approximately in 1835-1840.
archdesc.scopecontent: James Billings' letter to Nathaniel Stacy, mentioning many Michigan Universalist brethren, but mainly expressing Billings' uncertainty as to his best course, discussing risk in undertaking a publication. Also included with the original item a modern description of the letter and biographical information about Billings and Stacy.
